fulltext:
Möbius Transforms of Reynolds Operators
By John Boris Miller at Canberra ( Australia )
Abstract.  Certain Möbius ( i.  e.  bilinear ) transformations map Reynolds operators to Reynolds operators ; to wit,  those under which the systems of coaxal circles through 0 and 1 is invariant.  Conversely,  in appropriate circumstances,  the only holomorph ic functions which map Reynolds operators to Reynolds operators are these Möbius functions and possibly also certain compositions of Möbius and power functions.  This is because of the way in which the point spectrum of a Reynolds operator is disposed on the circles of the above coaxal system. 
1.  Notation.  Regular Reynolds operators and derivations
We use the following notation :
31 is a Banach algebra,  in general non-commutative,  over the complex field. 
33 ( 31 ) is the Banach algebra of bounded linear transformations mapping 31 into 3f,  with identity E, 
©( 31 ) is the class of closed linear transformations with domain and range in 31,  and having non-empty resolvent set. 
For A €©( 31 ), the ( extended ) resolvent set,  spectrum and point spectrum of К are respectively the following subsets of the extended complex plane :
Res ( ül ) = { Я : ( ÀE — Z )~^ exists as an element of 33 ( 31 )},
Sp ( AT ) == { Я : XE— К has no inverse in 33 ( 31 )}
PtSp ( if ) ~ { X : XE — К is not one-to-one }.
The domain of К is written î )( if ). We sometimes write Я ( Я,  К ) for { XE — K )~^; it is an element of 33 ( 31 ).
By a Reynolds operator we shall mean a transformation T in ©( 31 ) having the property
( 1.  1 ) ( E + T )( Tx ^ Ty ) = T ( Tx-y + x ^ Ty ) ( all x,  yi %{ T ))
It is assumed that %{ T ) is a subalgebra of 31,  and contains the range of Г,  which is necessarily also a subalgebra.  Linear operators satisfying ( 1.  1 ) on particular ( not necessarily normed ) algebras,  and subject to additional restrictions,  have been investigated in some detail ; references to the literature are given in [ 1 ], [ 2 ], [ 4 ] and [ 5 ].
By a derwation we shall mean a transformation D in ©( 3Ï ) with the property
( 1.  2 ) D { xy ) = Dx ' у + x • Dy ( all x,  y ^ %( D )),
It is assumed that ® { D ) is a subalgebra of 3f.  An example of a derivation is the commu tator
Ca of an element a € 31,  defined by CaX = ax — xa ; Ca ^ 33 ( 31 ).
We are concerned in this paper with aspects of the problem of generating Reynolds operators.  One source of Reynolds operators is from resolvents of derivations ; we have
